title: The Improvement of Black Raspberry in Obese and Mild AZ Patients Infected With H. Pylori
description_brief: The current study was designed to check the impact of black raspberry (BR) on obese and mild Alzheimers (AZ) patients infected with Helicobacter pylori (H pylori). Through checking various parameters including anthropometric, antioxidants, and CDR.
description_detailed:
The current study was designed to check the impact of black raspberry (BR) on obese and mild Alzheimers (AZ) patients infected with Helicobacter pylori (H pylori).

Preclinical studies (In vitro model) were conducted using 3T3-L1 adipocyte cells to check the anti-adhesion activity of BR.

For the clinical trial, a total of 21 obese mild AZ patients were recruited and separated into 2 groups: Experimental (BR group) and Placebo group.

Experimental group and Placebo group subjects were requested to take either 50 g of BR or 50 g of dextrin respectively for 4 weeks.
drug: black raspberry (Rubus occidentalis) — whole fruit / freeze-dried powder or extract (anthocyanin-rich)
explanation_target: Reason: The intervention is black raspberry (an anthocyanin-rich berry extract/powder) given to obese patients with mild Alzheimer’s disease and H. pylori infection, with outcomes including antioxidant measures and CDR (cognition). Anthocyanin-rich berry products are primarily antioxidant/anti-inflammatory nutraceuticals that have been tested for effects on memory and other cognitive domains rather than as biologic drugs targeting AD pathology (amyloid or tau). citeturn0search1turn1search1

Act (extracted details & web evidence): The trial uses black raspberry (BR) as the active intervention. Preclinical and in vitro studies show black/red raspberry extracts can inhibit Helicobacter pylori growth, and black raspberry preparations have antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects in animal models. These lines support the plausibility of effects on infection/oxidative stress but do not indicate a targeted anti-amyloid or anti-tau mechanism. citeturn0search4turn0search3

Additional evidence on cognition: Human trials and systematic reviews of anthocyanin-rich berry supplements (e.g., cherries, blackcurrant, mixed berry extracts) report improvements in some cognitive domains (short-term memory, verbal fluency, processing speed) or vascular/endothelial markers that may support cognitive benefit, consistent with a cognitive-enhancer / nutraceutical aim rather than a disease-targeted biologic or small molecule. citeturn1search0turn1search7

Reflect: Given (1) the intervention is a plant/food extract rich in anthocyanins (a nutraceutical), (2) measured outcomes include CDR and antioxidant markers rather than direct amyloid/tau endpoints, and (3) the literature frames berry anthocyanins as dietary cognitive-support agents, the correct category is 'cognitive enhancer'. There is ambiguity insofar as BR may have antimicrobial activity vs H. pylori (supporting a secondary aim) and anti-inflammatory effects that could be disease-modifying in theory, but no evidence the trial uses a biologic or small-molecule drug that directly targets Alzheimer pathology. Therefore 'cognitive enhancer' is the best fit. citeturn0search4turn1search1
explanation_agent: Reason: The intervention is an anthocyanin-rich black raspberry (Rubus occidentalis) preparation whose primary proposed biological actions in the trial are antioxidant (reducing oxidative stress) and related vascular/endothelial benefits that may support cognition. Systematic reviews/meta-analyses of berry anthocyanins emphasize antioxidant/vascular mechanisms as likely mediators of cognitive effects. citeturn0search7turn0search8

Act: Extracted details & web evidence: The trial drug is black raspberry (freeze‑dried powder or extract) rich in anthocyanins; preclinical and in vitro studies report antioxidant and anti‑inflammatory effects and direct antibacterial activity against Helicobacter pylori, supporting antioxidant/oxidative‑stress and anti‑infective mechanisms rather than direct anti‑amyloid or anti‑tau activity. Key supportive studies include a rat study showing decreased inflammatory markers and improved endothelial function after BR supplementation, in‑vitro/high‑throughput assays showing bactericidal activity of berry extracts vs H. pylori, and in‑vitro antioxidant/anti‑inflammatory assays for raspberry extracts. citeturn0search0turn0search3turn0search6

Reflect: Classification decision and alternatives: Because the trial explicitly measures antioxidant markers and uses an anthocyanin‑rich nutraceutical whose dominant mechanistic label is antioxidant activity, the most specific CADRO match is G) Oxidative Stress. There is overlap with anti‑inflammatory effects (CADRO F) and possible antimicrobial/vascular mechanisms (not specific CADRO pathology like amyloid/tau). If one emphasizes the multiple mechanisms (antioxidant + anti‑inflammatory + antimicrobial/vascular), R) Multi‑target could be defensible; however, given the trial’s stated outcomes (antioxidant measures) and the primary mechanistic rationale of anthocyanins, G) Oxidative Stress is the best single-category assignment. citeturn0search7turn0search0

Web evidence (selected search results used above): (1) Systematic review: Effects of berry anthocyanins on cognitive performance, vascular function and cardiometabolic markers (supports cognitive/vascular links to anthocyanin antioxidant actions). citeturn0search7 (2) Meta-analysis/systematic review of anthocyanins on cognition (summarizes human RCT evidence for cognitive benefits of anthocyanins). citeturn0search8 (3) High-throughput metabolic microarray and organoid study showing antibacterial effects of black/red raspberry extracts against H. pylori. citeturn0search3 (4) Rat study showing black raspberry reduces inflammatory markers and improves endothelial function in a high‑fat diet model (supports anti‑inflammatory/vascular effects). citeturn0search0 (5) In vitro studies demonstrating antioxidant and anti‑inflammatory activity of raspberry extracts/seed oil. citeturn0search6turn0search4
